<title>2.7.Eigendecomposition</title></head>
<body><ul>
<li>You should read about <em>eigenvectors</em> and <em>eigenvalues</em> in <a href='https://khoablog.github.io/2020/03/05/math-6' style='color:green'>MATH_6</a>  to be able to understand the following.</li>

</ul>
<h5><strong>2.7. Eigendecomposition</strong></h5>
<ul>

<li><p>Similarly, we can decompose a matrix into a set of <em>eigenvectors</em> and <em>eigenvalues</em>, it called <em>eigendecompose</em>.</p>

</li>

</li>
<li><p>We have seen <em>constructing</em> matrices with specific <em>eigenvectors</em> and <em>eigenvalues</em> allows us to stretch space in desired directions.</p>
<p>
    <img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/khoatranrb/Img4Md/master/B/DL1/dl1-1.png">
</p>
</li>
<li><p>However, not  every matrix can be decomposed into <em>eigenvectors</em> and <em>eigenvalues</em>. In some cases, some <em>eigenvalues</em> are complex number. At this, we can use only real-valued <em>eigenvalues</em> and <em>eigenvectors</em>:</p>

</li>
<li><p>The <em>eigendecomposition</em> tells us some useful fact about the matrix:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>The matrix is singular if and only if any the <em>eigenvalues</em> are zero.</p>
</li>
<li><p>The <em>eigendecomposition</em> of real symmetric matrix can be used to optimize quadratic expressions of the form <span class="MathJax_SVG" tabindex="-1" style="font-size: 100%; display: <ul>
<li><p>Whenever <span class="MathJax_SVG" tabindex="-1" style="font-size: 100%; display: inline-block;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.226ex" height="1.293ex" viewBox="0 -504.6 528 556.9" role="img" focusable="false" style="vertical-align: -0.121ex;"><defs><path stroke-width="0" id="E28-MJMAIN-78" d="M201 0Q189 3 102 3Q26 3 17 0H11V46H25Q48 47 67 52T96 61T121 78T139 96T160 122T180 150L226 210L168 288Q159 301 149 315T133 336T122 351T113 363T107 370T100 376T94 379T88 381T80 383Q74 383 44 385H16V431H23Q59 429 126 429Q219 429 229 431H237V385Q201 381 201 369Q201 367 211 353T239 315T268 274L272 270L297 304Q329 345 329 358Q329 364 327 369T322 376T317 380T310 384L307 385H302V431H309Q324 428 408 428Q487 428 493 431H499V385H492Q443 385 411 368Q394 360 377 341T312 257L296 236L358 151Q424 61 429 57T446 50Q464 46 499 46H516V0H510H502Q494 1 482 1T457 2T432 2T414 3Q403 3 377 3T327 1L304 0H295V46H298Q309 46 320 51T331 63Q331 65 291 120L250 175Q249 174 219 133T185 88Q181 83 181 74Q181 63 188 55T206 46Q208 46 208 23V0H201Z"></path></defs><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><use xlink:href="#E28-MJMAIN-78" x="0" y="0"></use></g></svg></span><script type="math/tex">\mathbb{x}</script> is equal to an <em>eigenvector</em> of <span class="MathJax_SVG" tabindex="-1" style="font-size: 100%; </li>
<li><p><span class="MathJax_SVG" tabindex="-1" style="font-size: 100%; display: inline-block;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="23.331ex" height="2.577ex" viewBox="0 -806.1 </li>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</li>
<li><p>A matrix whose <em>eigenvalues</em> are all positive is called <strong>positive definite</strong>. A matrix whose <em>eigenvalues</em> are all positive or zero valued is called <strong>positive semidefinite</strong>. If all <em>eigenvalues</em> are negative, the matrix is <strong>negative definite</strong>.</p>
</li>
